description:
One of the great SF traditions!  Everyone should try this at least once.  It's a very fun, safe and easy ride through town.  Don't be afraid to show up completely naked; you won't be alone!

EDIT:  I have to say this in light of the recent event where a masser was seen damaging a car with a U-lock:  that is not at all what CM is about.  The purpose of this ride is not to shit on your neighbors.  Enjoy the ride and the comradery.  Don't be a jackass!
author: Ron B.

description: Look at me I'm an adult acting like a spoiled child! Out of my way or I'll start crying and hit you with my u-lock! Why I'll just drive my suv across the bay to then get on my bicycle and act like a total ass-hat! Here I am decked out in full spanx like lance armstrong so I can ride to the corner store and buy a vape pen!
author: Grace S.

description:
I wonder how many drive to CM in their SUVs from out of town.

It's bad enough that in the past when traffic was relatively normal, they'd screw it up in total disregard of the law. Now that hellzapoppin' with all the construction downtown, on a bad Friday night it can take 45 minutes to get from the Hyatt Embarcadero to the Bay Bridge -- maybe 0.6 miles -- without Critical Mass. Today's (4/27/2018) CM is, then, the very epitome of douchebaggery.

If SFPD ever give those jerks a police escort again, those who agree with me should petition the Superior Court for (1) a Writ of Prohibition forbidding SFPD from escorting any group through the streets except as provided for by law and (2) a finding that mere resolutions by the Board of Supervisors do NOT have the force of law.

And let me say this to tonight's Crtical Massers. I'll put it as politely as possible:

IF YOU'RE riding YOUR BICYCLE, please STAY OFF THE FUCKING SIDEWALK.
author: David N.

description: Mister Chao hates these bike riders.  They should be persecuted as a gang for disrupting peoples lives, breaking traffic laws, creating a safety hazards, and endanger pedestrians.
author: Mister Chao ..

description:
A group of mostly white, middle class, rude, arrogant entitled men who terrorize motorists while they violate every possible traffic rule and endanger pedestrians and believe that thuggery and intimidation are protected free speech. 

Here's a link to their typical behavior: http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2015/08/31/video-shows-critical-mass-cyclist-smashing-car-window-with-u-lock-san-francisco/
author: Steve L.

description:
Any comment from Critical Mass on the recent tragedy and a plead of innocence for the death of an elderly pedestrian ? Seems like the mass is not holy (they hold mass when they are impelled to)  nor quite enough mass to muster an opinion. 

http://www.sfgate.com/?controllerName=search&action=search&channel=crime&search=1&inlineLink=1&query=%22Chris+Bucchere%22
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Apparently my last review of Critical Mass was a little too harsh and got removed.  

Oh well, I'll try and be nicer this time:  Every single criminal participating in this event is a waste of life.
author: Brendan B.

description: Bicyclists shout to share the road when they never share themselves.  I do all I can to obey the traffic laws as well as respect everyone on the road, sidewalk, bike lane...the idea that riding s bike gives you license to do what you want and the idea that by driving a car I'm a villain is complete nonsense.
author: Ray A.

description:
Last year I got caught trying to cross the street (on my own bike mind you) during this event, after trying to cross the street i had three "hipsters" stop and verbally accost me. 

I would highly encourage anyone with some extra thumb tacks or a box of jacks lying around to witness this event for yourself.
author: Brian K.

description:
Critical Mass never gets a parade permit or files a parade route. They claim to be "ordinary traffic", but they consistently fail to obey the rules of the road, run red lights en masse, and require a police escort. A parade permit, when properly filed and paid for, means that MUNI can reroute traffic around the mess and the cops get paid for the overtime and extra shifts. Critical Mass' refusal to do so costs the City money, as well as annoying a lot of people. It should grow up and file a parade permit like any other event. Suggest this to your supervisors.

Critical Mass blocks taxis, buses, and paratransit, not to mention emergency services. It is obviously not disabled-friendly. Don't tell me to get my crippled ass on a bike. I will stick my cane in your wheels. Oh, and: get off my sidewalk and wheelchair ramps.
author: Anne K.

description: Cyclists in San Francisco are the new entitled homeless. They suck more out of the system than they pay.  I do not need to say more.
author: Coyote B.

description: A bunch of clowns riding around the city causing mischief; that's what the majority of them are. At one point in time this was a legitimate protest, but it's not anymore. It's just a shit show now. I love bicycling and I support the city doing things to make cycling safer and more convenient, but there are a lot of goons in the critical mass movement who are not helping the cause. It's about time the SF police started cracking down on them.
author: Don W.

description: The behavior of many in Critical Mass is appalling. Sadly, the good intentions of this movement seem to have vanished. Why is more not being done to protect the public from these people?
author: Robert B.

description:
Your goals include impeding traffic by blowing through red lights in dense packs and displacing cars. Wow.
Take a tip from SF Bike Party and follow the rules of traffic on your mass rides. I am a cycling supporter but aggressive, selfish cycling habits are disruptive and counterproductive for bay area public relations. Brash actions have undesirable rippling consequences from giving the public a negative opinion of cyclists to causing commuters to miss appointments.
Take advice from real cyclists such as SF Bicycle Coalition and "Share the Road."
author: Carrie H.

description:
Critical mass ruins my entire day every time it happens. 

San Francisco might be one of the most bike friendly cities in the world and all you idiots are doing is making everyone hate cyclists more than they already do.

So THANKS a bunch for making me re-arrange my Friday night commute once a month. It's delightful.
author: Jess T.

description:
I am an avid cyclist. But I HATE Critical Mass. I hope people don't think all cyclist are that ignorant of people's need to get somewhere. 

Have they think, "what if?' 
what if someone was sick and needed to get to hospital?
what if someone was hurry to get home to their children?

I love bicycle, but will never be a part of this Critical Mess.
author: Mika G.

description:
It's long been overdue to admit that, whatever the original intent might have been, Critical Mass is now just a roving drunken party, thinly justified by some muddled, selfish hipster kid conception of anarchist philosophy.

Stated goals of Critical Mass: Increase vehicle driver awareness of cyclists and the injury they can cause to them. Challenge people to contemplate their "auto dependence." 

Actual accomplishments of Critical Mass: Make working people who rely on city buses late for work and school. Make working people who are just trying to drive home after a long day of work sit and wait on them, further driving a wedge between cyclists and motorists. Piss off motorists by harassing them and generally acting like dickbags, fueling their repressed anger towards cyclists - at best helping to generate opposition to future ballot measures that might make streets more bike-friendly,  at worst making it more likely they'll take a swipe at a cyclist at some point in the future when they see an opportunity and think they can get away with it. 

Thanks, Revolutionary Heroes. Really appreciate the work you're doing for us proletariat.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
This is nothing to lighten up about. I have seen people drunk. I have seen laws broken. IF this is part of the original philosophy keep it to yourself. I am glad some find it fun in an innocent way, however once you start to break laws, and harass pedestrians and traffic itself, you should be treated as a you have committed a crime. 

I hope the cops crack down harder. There needs to be more cops present if there are cops normally. This event is becoming a burden on the city. It needs to be organized and there needs to be someone/entity/org that takes responsibility for unlawful participants. 

I feel bad for the good apples in this group, but you image is being tarnished. Please filter the bad apples out before someone gets hurt.
author: Ahmed D.

description:
Just a note to all the Critical mAssholes...

Stop it.  Go away.  I watched an old man and his wife get assaulted by a mob of these pricks because he was trying to cross an intersection when he had a green light.  The bicyclists proceeded to beat on his car with a variety of implements.  The couple was like 80.  The poor gal looked terrified.  

Just go bike somewhere else.
author: Peter M.

description:
I was walking in the Castro a month ago. A friend and I started to cross the street in the crosswalk where there were stop signs. A dozen cyclists came riding into the intersection without stopping and brushed up against me (as if we were supposed dodge them) as my friend and I got stuck in the middle of the intersection. Thanks, Critical Massholes, for making it apparent that pedestrians, with no helmets or wheels, somehow need to be taught a lesson. Your movement is stupid, chaotic and hiding barrels and barrels of bad apples. All the good apples left when they saw the ugliness lurking in your midst thanks to that Zip car bashing video  You want to prove that one day a month you can have the streets to yourselves like spoiled punks? Well, good job!  Mission accomplished. Angry cyclists can make a statement of idiocy in masses. Yay! Go back to your Grand Theft Auto games and re-think your value system. Oh, and I noticed that you never updated your website to own the Zip car bashing video. Cowards - cowards who corner and attack a driver using a shared car program to reduce automobiles.

To make matters worse, the police were escorting the massholes in the Castro instead of protecting the public. What side are the police on???  Fire the police chief. This is wacko policy. Pedestrians ALWAYS have the right of way. I'd like to see the permit the massholes don't have and that allows them police protection (ergo costing the city money and reducing police elsewhere).  This needs to stop.

Update: The police chief has been fired. I recommend that pedestrians speak up about dangerous cyclists.
author: L L.

description:
Critical Mass is one of those very few things that will make you momentarily hate SF. 
 My usual reminder that it is the last Friday of the month comes when I realize that my usually ride home (muni) is not going to be arriving anytime soon. At which point I find a cab.
author: John O.

description:
Say what you will about Critical Mass.  Until you ride you just dont get it.

I found a documentary on Youtube about the starts of Critical Mass.  Very informative of the roots of how it all started.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVnWcrDDaLI

I'll be back in San Francisco next year...I cant wait to ride again!!
author: Dorsey S.

description:
Oh I get it trust me. You are an anti establishment crusader. Something severely lacking here in San Francisco. *soak up the sarcasm* 

And I tooootally get your disdain for the man. But did any of you ever stop to think that you are nothing but a roaming pain in the ass for the rest of the people that may or may not share in your ideals?? 

You cut off traffic, you accost anyone that is trying to pass by your entourage of "idealists" and you send a general message that its okay to fuck over the city you hold so dear by acting like a bunch of drunken tards that disrupt the flow. 

Your goal is counterproductive and you just come across as a group of jobless goofs that think that you are actually sending a message to anyone. Grow the fuck up. No one respects your selfish plight, and your event is nothing but a clusterfuck of douchebags that find any excuse to get hammered and ride around in sophomoric fashion like kids on a bitchfest looking for any reason to keep your middle aged ass relevant to the protesting scene. 

If you ever get shot down by a paintball to the face you know it was me.
author: Dru P.

description:
Nothing better than when a collection of low crime vandals, bitter millennials with credit card debt and/or student loans, hypocritical environmentalists, naive hipsters attempting to address issues in white privilege alongside the irony of their implicit isolationist mentalities, and people with humanities degrees taking out their anger regarding economic and social inequality on similarly financially struggling car owners or rental car drivers get together and collectively decide to defy every traffic law in existence. O wait, anything's better than this pisspoor excuse for mostly white hipsters lacking the most rudimentary levels of creativity to emulate a tradition with even the SAME name across a multitude of world class cities. In Poland, the police intervened. If you partake in this tradition, then you consciously know that you are breaking the law. You are defying laws built to ensure our collective security on the road. If you partake in this tradition, which like most elements of hipster urban culture originate from exploited customs and traditions across a variety of cultures and NOT from the epiphanies of privileged hipsters from upper middle class backgrounds, then you deserve to be prosecuted under the law. I hope all of you low life vandals understand why my fellow civilians refuse to respect most of you bikers. You're all nothing but boring, entitled, mostly originating from upper middle class background, pathetic hipster wannabes with a variety of psychological issues which you consciously take out on innocent bystanders. From people just trying to make a living delivering demeaning take out food to college students trying to get to class on time to your average person trying to have just a few hours of leisure, you people are no different than common street vandals. Ironically, you all manage to get away with this every month due to either white privilege or your overwhelming numbers. All of you should be fined and prosecuted under the law, especially you angry hipsters. I have no respect for you law breaking vandals lacking even subtle traces of original creativity. Stop doing this on our streets. I will do my part in prosecuting as many of you as I can, and I urge my fellow San Franciscans to do their part as well. 

Get some originality, stop demanding respect if you're going to defy our uniform street laws, stop putting the public's safety at risk, and stop thinking that as long as you have white privilege in a massive group with others who share such privilege that you are above the law. You scum make me sick.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I'm a cyclist. Hell, I might even be considered a cycling advocate. I've gone to city planning meetings, I've campaigned for road diets and reduced parking. I'm even a member of a few cycling non-profits. I've been known to bike to school, to work, and even to job interviews in a suit. I'm even so crazy as to wake up extra early so I can ride my bike. Even so, I have a hard time justifying Critical Mass.

I can't deny that it has done great things for cycling advocacy in the past, and that's the only thing stopping it from getting one star. However, I think the cycling community as a whole would benefit from a very different approach to advocacy than that espoused by Critical Mass. People bike, the message has been sent.

 However, I don't think the image that the cyclist community needs right now is the one Critical Mass gives us. The giant rolling party only serves to reinforce the notion that there is a separation between drivers and cyclists, an unbridgeable gap. I ride my bike a lot, but sometimes I walk, and sometimes I even get into a car; when I do one, I don't immediately throw away my identity as the rest. There is no 'Other' in this case.

I think that cyclist would be better served by being normal people who just happen to be on bikes, just as drivers are people who happen to be in cars.
author: Herbert S.

description:
I wish I could give this event 0 stars. I have managed to avoid CM for the past few years (I still don't own a car, by the way), but I finally got caught up in it one more time. In this event, the Critical Massholes decided to ride in a circle around the intersection of Van Ness Ave. and Mission, which is a linchpin intersection for getting from South of Market out of the city. The Critical Massholes managed to block that one intersection for over 10 minutes, causing hundreds of cars to sit there idling. One particular fuckhead was heckling the drivers who were stuck at the intersection.

I manfully resisted the temptation to drive my car straight through their formation.
author: Bitter J.

description:
Critical Mass is a "peaceful" reminder that we are all "addicted" to fossil fuel, and why don't we all just stay out of our cars.  And it's "great fun!"  Remember, bikes aren't "destroying nature" or "our planet."

Fun facts to keep in mind:

1.  Bikes are mass produced by the millions and transported to big-box stores, each element a piece of the grand supply chain of global commerce, which means international shipping, cheap, third-world industrial labor, etc. etc.  

So unless our friendly Critical Mass riders are only buying organic, free-range, compassionately-raised, locally-grown bikes, there's at least a tad bit of hypocrisy oozing out of their sweaty pores.
 
2.  While Critical Mass might be a "fun" reminder of how we need to save the planet, in reality it creates a giant traffic jam that leaves more cars idling, obviously producing more carbon emissions than they would otherwise.

3.  Why not just leave that car at home one day a month?  Take public transport!  Enjoy some exercise.

Translation:  after all, we all work at Google and get free lunches and have infinitely flexible schedules and on-demand telecommuting.  There aren't any hard-working, blue collar folks with kids who can't just blow off their daily commute one day.  Not in the Bay Area.  It's inconceivable that our monthly "fun" actually causes great hardship to the individuals who most need to be convinced of the need to "save the planet" ... and who have the least means to do so ...

But of course none of this matters, because this is San Francisco, and public disruption needs only the thinnest veil of legitimacy to take place.  

I don't have much skin the bikes-versus-cars debate.  I certainly don't mind people having fun.  But don't wrap yourself in the freakin' flag of the public good when it's obvious to any rational observer that you're being obnoxious and causing a hardship.  

Anyway, one star, but it's more for city government's failure to crack down than the riders themselves.  What do we pay taxes for again?
author: J W.

description:
Wait.. what's this? Is there a sale on Ulocks? Perhaps the local GAP is giving away skinny jeans? Surely, it must be something important!

Nope, it's just a bunch of self-absorbed hipsters breaking traffic laws and preventing emergency vehicles from getting through.

As a cyclist myself, I absolutely detest Critical Mass. If you want to "share the road" and have "rights like cars" be sure to pickup a DMV manual and read up on TRAFFIC RULES.  You know, those things you don't bother to adhere to? 

Until you learn to play nice with others on the road and actually obey the laws, there are plenty of independently-owned coffee shops you can park your asses at while you do something creative on your Macbook.
author: Serge S.

description:
F you critical mass. You serve no purpose.

See, I sold my car to do zipcar because I wanted to do good for the environment, make one more parking spot, get a car off the road, and save myself money because you don't need a car here. I walk everywhere and when I can't I take public transportation. I am also a big carpooler. I bike sometimes and I am totally on board with bikers and more bike lanes in the city.

But when I want to go out to a nice dinner, and your retarded antics make our cab have to go ridiculously out of the way because there is no way to cross from castro to mission and I have to be late to dinner and spend more than TWICE what I would on the cab for this little detour, i think you should have to pay my fare.

Again, myself, the other reviewers and the rest of the muni patrons are the ones who are getting screwed here. Those with cars are able to go around. So please, what the hell is your point?
author: Nikki M.

description: The whole concept reeks of immaturity to me.  I wonder if these people will feel the same way in 10 years when they grow up a bit.
author: Thomas D.

description: Let me join in by saying the critical mass blows.  Was there from the beginning when they were kicking people's cars and blocking traffic.
author: Bjj P.

description:
Lighten up, baby! It's a few minutes of your life, that's all.

And that's the point really. To make you pause.

You can use that time to boil in your own anger. Or you can use that time ponder dependency on automobiles. 

And if you're giving Critical Mass a one star rating, then you know who you are.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
I dedicate each CM ride to all the drivers who cut me off, who are parallel parked and open doors or pull out without looking (esp. feel the love along the Embarcadero!), and to all those who find it necessary to drive in or on the border of the bike lane for shits and giggles.  
-Being late and sitting in traffic for 1 pre-determined day of the month beats dealing with aggressive drivers everyday.
-Quit your bitchin, grab a bike, and join the ride.
author: tiff g.

description:
Very rare for me to give one star.  You're the second lucky one.  

You completely block traffic for mass transportation and give people a miserable hell for taking a bus home on a Friday night.  Thanks and get a life.  Whatever your message is, it's lost because you just seem like a bunch of whiners who are rejected by society and have to passive-aggressively take it out on decent mass transit commuters.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Would give 0-stars if I could.  

I'm a biker. When I used to work in the city, I almost always biked to work. As long as you're not being a complete ass-hat and breaking all the traffic laws (as you shouldn't be), people at least respected you. And you weren't going around terrorizing the pedestrians. But if you're that prick who decides he/she can run lights, hog an entire lane and purposely bike slowly to exert some sort of civil disobedience or self-righteousness, or just generally bike around like a complete idiot, you shouldn't deserve to ride in the city. Or anywhere for that matter - you ARE being a complete menace. 

Critical-Mass is just like that, only on a much larger scale. Same self-righteous, self-important attitudes, same sense of entitlement and superiority, and complete ignorance. Glad they're undermining the cause that they think they're trying to support. Which I'm sure they've completely forgotten about. Or never knew in the first place.

Oh, and also, making a left turn at the no-left turn intersection on the Polk Street side of the Broadway tunnel, and loitering in the middle of the street, but thinking you're protected because you're part of the "mass" of bikers on the ride that are nowhere to be found around you - bad idea.

Douche-dom.
author: Nicholas T.

description:
Don't knock it 'til you've tried it.  

Looks like this is a big venting wall for those who have been miffed in some way by the chaotic parade that is Critical Mass. I, too, have been held up by the parade and I've witnessed some bad behavior, yet as a regular cyclist, I can't help but find Critical Mass to be an incredibly liberating experience. Not all of the participants ride like an assholes -- just like people actually run in Bay to Breakers, folks actually ride like civilized bicyclists in CM. There's a great sense of community and pride involved that's upstaged by people's frustration.

Can't we all just get along? Grab a bike and let's roll!
author: Marie S.

description: Let me ride a bike with no purpose and cause traffic and ignore the laws of the road after everyone has worked a long work week and just want to get home to their family. Let's forget about the purpose to get people on our side  and just piss everyone off.by being inconsiderate bike riders. Honestly I would respect this cause more if they "shared the road " which is bicyclists biggest complaints with drivers. But just causing mad traiffic for everyone and running red lights for 30+ minutes. Goof job causijg opposite affect to have people not support ur cause and be a douche rider to prove nothing. I wasn't even in the traffic until now and saw from nearby restaurant how classless this event was. I am all about proving ur point but this is ridiculous. Get a life.
author: Kai T.

description:
From criticalmass.info "How to" section:

"4. Don't get a permit.....The point of Critical Mass is that biking is a right, not a privilege. Cars don't need permits to ride on the streets, and neither should cyclists."

Um, does he know what vehicle registration is?

I just thought that exemplified how naive and clueless the massholes are. Remember guys, you wanted the laws, and you got them: bikes are vehicles too, with rights and responsibilities, including YIELDING TO PEDESTRIANS.  

 So, before you ride, ask yourself: "Knowing that I'm creating traffic and CO2 from idling cars, reducing the effectiveness of public transportation like buses, and openly flaunting the vehicle laws that CM was supposed to create awareness of, am I doing this for a cause or to make my feel more self-righteous than I already do?"
author: Robert F.

description: Is there any more efficient way to turn people, who would normally support your cause, against you than to design an event expressly to piss people off? Fuck these guys.
author: Matthew K.

description:
The last critical mass, I was on the F-line trying to make my BART train.  Critical mass caused the line car to stop a block from the drop-off point for the Embarcadero BART station.  After about 10 minutes of sitting on MUNI, I decided that waiting for the bikes to pass was ridiculous and I should just walk the hundred yards to the station's stairs.

I felt about as safe as a squirrel crossing the Autobahn.  Moreover, I kept getting yelled at to "Get out of the f-ing way, girl!" which was hard to do since I didn't know where to f-ing go.  I understand the desire for bicycle awareness on the roads, but I don't think that the way to go about achieving awareness AND support is to act like a flaming idiot.

Maybe cars would be mindful of cyclists' rights and "ease off the gas" if the critical masses would ease off the crazy.
author: Rachel S.

description: I am all for riding a bicycle. At current gas prices I might start doing it just to defy the Oil companies.  However I disagree with the method this organization uses to promotes bike riding.  Critical Mass gives you the impression that they are antagonistic, confrontational and pisses off everyone, pedestrians, motorists, mother pushing a stroller, you name it.  I mean everyone!
author: Jim J.

description:
As a former bicycle messenger, I can say with some authority, Fuck Critical Mass! BTW, the lie that the San Francisco Bicycle Coalition does not endorse the event is FUCKING BULLSHIT.  I was a member of the SFBC, and they tacitly endorse the event.  Every time Leah Shahum denies affiliation or endorsement by the SFBC, her credibility sinks.

I speak for a large number of bike messengers when I say; I fucking HATE critical mass. All the pretty pretty little hipsters go out on Friday night during rush hour while people are trying to pick-up their kids from daycare, or start their weekends. The Massers self-righteously and intentionally harass and provoke the drivers. Who pays the bills for this? Regular bike communters and bicycle messengers who have to deal with the seething on Monday and the rest of the month.
author: M. J.

description: I watched bicyclists stop in front of a car and keep it from moving. The driver was stuck for 15 minutes, one block away from his hotel, and he had just arrived from the airport. Way to welcome someone to our city :(
author: Sean D.

description:
To everyone who gave this 4 or more stars thank you, i know you the 1 out of millions who commute in the city everyday on a bike, or any city with that matter. 

Before you start to judge I used to be a daily driver before I sold my car and got a bike to become more green. I only ran in CM three times my whole life, keep in mind I'm from the city, yes born and raised. When I first had my CM experience as a driver I was like WTF is this? I thought it was more amazing then annoying, I had nowhere to be it was after work no biggie. I know your like "I just got off work and I just wanna get home" guess who's the one being selfish now? 

To all the people who gave this 1 star grab the closest blunt object and use it to bang your head in the back of your skull, you'll be helping the rest of the world. trust me. If it really bothers you that much and if your really care about emissions and stuff then how about not driving and taking public transportation on the last Friday of every month. Not only will you make it easier for you but you'll make it easier for us as well. Its a win-win, get it?  

If you still don't understand let me turn the tables. Do you yelp local freeway jams? now that stops traffic more then CM. Doesn't seem like you care about the emissions then...? 

We have the same laws as a motor vehicle (IF you ever read the DMV handbook) so treat us like one, so what if we take up an whole lane, guess what? it the law we are a vehicle so zip it. CM is once a month not everyday or once a week or every two weeks, its just one day out of 29 days in the month.
author: Louis C.

description:
Do I really need to explain one star for Critical Mass?  They're lucky they got the one.  Yelp, how about adding capability for 0 or negative stars?

There's a myriad of reasons to despise Critical Mass.  The most obvious are the self-defeating environmental reasons noted by others.  Here's my worst reason to hate them (and yes, I realize how strong a word "hate" is):

On Halloween 2008, the band I was in was lucky enough to play the City's event and its large stage.  It was my first gig here in San Francisco and for a musician used to skeevy bars (literally the last gig I played before moving out here, that venue got condemned the week after we played), this was a godsend.  More importantly, it was supposed to be the first time my sister got to see her baby brother perform; for years we lived on opposite coasts.  Instead, Critical Mass held up the 38 and 47 busses she needed to take from the Inner Richmond.

Critical Mass, you owe me big.  You owe me a priceless family moment.  One that can never be repeated.  May you all be ticketed and rot in Hell.
author: Jim S.

description:
These people are bunch of criminals.  In fact, if the same yardstick of Domestic Terror laws were applied to Critical Mass participants and leadership, they would all be spirited away to prisons in the middle of the night.  They are terrorists, whose only goal is to disrupt traffic in the city during peek hours and harrass motorists.

Why the SFPD doesn't start locking them up, and shutting the whole Critical Mass operation down is a mystery ... THEY ARE CRIMINALS!
author: Doug L.

description:
I am all for eco transport. I have a green blog. I have a bus pass. I'm selling my car next week. However, these jerks give bikers (and San Francisco. and hipsters. and humans.) a bad reputation. 

Today I waited almost 40 minutes for a bus that was supposed to come in 6. I finally gave up, and found an underground. Keeping people from taking public transportation? The day before Halloween? Lame. Uber lame. And this gang isn't just annoying. It's reckless and dangerous, too.

However, since I can't give it 0 stars and am forced to grant 1, I will admit this. One dude was dressed as Jesus, and a biker behind him shouted, "Jesus Christ, get out of the way!" That was damn funny. You're funny, but you're still a d'bag.
author: Janet G.

description:
I've done it once, and...

1. I felt like a complete asshole doing the ride, 
2. I don't understand this... you are all cycling for bikers rights yet you come out in droves and break traffic laws?
3. You are almost all complete ass holes. I saw multiple people throw out elbows and try to kick LITTLE OLD LADIES who wanted to cross the street and get to their opera/ ballet/ symphony show. When you are not cycling, you too are a pedestrian, show some human decency and respect. 
4. admittedly, it looks quite impressive... only if you are in no hurry to go anywhere or are just looking out your window while the herd speeds by. 
5. I like to cycle, I try to be on my bike as much as possible, but I will never again join in on critical mass. 

xoxo

description:
As a daily SF bicycle commuter, I wish CM would go away.  I understand when it first started, it was a sincere protest and helped launch the SFBC and get some true bicycle improvements onto the city's agenda.

But from what I can see right now, it's just a rolling party, with many out of towners looking to have a good time (see the other comment about the co-worker putting his bike on the back of his SUV to drive to SF to ride in CM, ughh).

But for all you road ragers out there, while CM sucks, when it comes to normal day to day traffic, remember to give some respect to the cyclists on the road... we have a right to be there just like you, and even though we may slow you down every now and then for 3 or 4 seconds, that's one less car on the road, one less parking spot being taken up, etc.

And for you cyclists out there... be sure to yield to peds and cars when it's their right of way.  Running a stop sign on a bike is like a car going 5 mph over the limit (btw, the speed limit in SF is 25 unless posted otherwise) -- everyone does it, so we should just get over it... just don't cut people off and wait your turn and we'll all be happily on our way.

description:
This review is mainly about the ride from the perspective from someone who has done a few Critical Mass (CM) rides in another town.  I'm not here to discuss the philosophy behind it.  Where I'm from, CM has a de facto leadership, rides a few miles on a set course with regular stops that last for 1/2 hour or more to drink alcohol, too many like to race rather than ride and riders gets harassed by the cops.  I quit attending for the last few months since the altercations with the cops would just kill the mood for the ride.  But I was in town in SF for Halloween weekend and figured that I had to participate since this is where CM originated at.   So how was it?  To put it mildly, it didn't suck.  In fact it was one of the best events I've been to in quite a while.  

On every last Friday of the month, cyclists from around town gathers around 530pm at the Justin Herman Plaza and ride starts around 6.  Occupy SF was in the same area so it was interesting to see that there too.  Here at CM SF, there is no leadership.  It becomes a force of nature once the ride starts going.  Cars are trying to get through but they are prevented by other massers that cork the intersections to protect everyone else on the ride.  I was actually surprised that the the police provided some motorcycle escorts for the ride instead of cracking down on cyclists.  We filled the streets with cyclists and rode for miles but we didn't stop.  People were wearing all sorts of costumes.  And the bikes with sound systems...they just keep one upping each other in noise level and the bass was pulsating through the crowd.  A girl (not from SF also visiting from TX) who I was riding along with said that participating in CM made her entire trip to SF worthwhile.  The whole experience was A-MAZ-ING and I would attend CM in SF again.
author: John F.

description:
I love how critical mass is listed under "local flavor" - yeah, its got a  flavor alright.  One that leaves a very unpleasant, bitter aftertaste....

Got stuck in the middle of this group for the first time on my way home from a dance class - it was a lovely combo of critical mass riders and traffic from the ballpark.  Fortunately, I wasn't in a big rush to get anywhere.

Let me first say that I don't drive around the city very often - I take BART to work and walk to as many places as I can (and there is no way I'd take my life into my hands by biking around downtown SF - I've seen too many accidents to even consider that one.) But, I DO need to drive my very fuel efficient car on some occasions!

I truly don't understand how this group expects to gain ANY sympathy for their "cause" by pissing off drivers, pedestrians, and the riders who get stuck on buses.   I really think its less of a true cause for most of these people and more of an opportunity to have a few moments of power that they normally don't have when they are riding around the city.  The smugness and sense of superiority that this group emits is also something that will also not gain them any support.  It just pisses people off and probably makes them want to drive more, not less.  How many of those drivers, after being delayed and putting up with the verbal abuse from some riders, do you think went home and said, "gee, I think I'll start riding my bike more often"?  I'm guessing none.... 

They need to realize that biking is not an option for everyone. And while we should all be conscious about using alternate forms of transportation whenever possible, buying fuel-efficient cars when we can, there are times when we just have to be in our cars.  California does not have a public transportation system that is widespread or efficient enough for people to substantially reduce their reliance on their cars.  San Francisco is better than some cities, but definitely does not deserve any awards for its limited, often delayed, public transportation system.  The city could look to better examples, such as Chicago's system, to improve people's ability to get around town and between major metropolitan areas.  In order to get more cars off the city streets, perhaps CM could better use their time and resources by advocating for better public transportation options within the city.
author: Kimberly T.

description: While I love the idea of Critical Mass, the support of alternative transportation and peaceful protest, I cannot support your movement at this time.  I agree with Cara Y. wholeheartedly when she states that you as protesters want all the respect of the roadway due a motorist, and indeed this is the law.  However, you refuse to follow the rules.  This weekend I am in SF visiting a sick and dying friend and I had to wait on Halloween night in a taxicab with the meter ticking for you people to ride through 6+ changes of light.  We all have needs, places to go and things to do. If you want the same respect as cars and for us treat you as equals then please obey the same rules, which includes stopping at the god damned traffic lights.

San Francisco needs to get on the same tip as other Bay Area cities, such as Berkeley - PERMITS & REGISTRATION!!!  Until the time comes where you're licensed & insured, I can't respect you; until you're expected to pay for damages you've inflicted on my car because you're an IDIOT & know that you can get away with it, there's no way that I'll ever feel comfortable sharing the road with you. I'm a native, & I get the lib attitude; however, if any other group of LAWBREAKERS assembled & created the kind of drama for which you're paying out OT to SFPD for these idiots to do, you'd have them locked up in a NY minute...as I said earlier - ENOUGH IS ENOUGH!!!
author: Amoura B.

description:
All I have to say is F*CK critical mass and the people involved. I am a bicyclist and attended a few years back and all I have to say is what f*cking disrespect. As bicyclists we should be setting a good example so people will respect us. Instead what I saw was a bunch of assholes causing trouble for motorists. I saw one motorist who was trying to drive down the street get circled by a bunch of cyclists who refused to move and kept the driver from being able to get wherever he was trying to go. To make things worse, the driver honked and cyclists started kicking his car and slapping and punching his windows with great force. I thought, okay, there's a few bad apples in the bunch. I kept riding and tried to have a good time. A lot of the cyclists were in good spirits and I actually met some really nice people, until 20 minutes later. I saw the same incident happen. A car was circled at an intersection by 15+ angry cyclists. The lady driving the car had a child in the front seat and 2 in the back. She rolled down the window and yelled to get out of the way and the cyclists surrounding her car started yelling obscenities at her and kicking and hitting her windows. The children in the car looked terrified and the small boy in the backseat started crying his eyes out. I was happy to see a couple other cyclists come up, including myself, and start yelling at the cyclists who were surrounding her car. Myself and 3 or 4 other cyclists physically had to push the aggressive cyclists out of the way and clear a path for her. That was the final straw for me. I hopped on my bike and went home.

I thought I was going to be attending a fun bike rally and instead I was witnessing uncontrolled chaos. I honestly wouldn't have minded if the drivers being harassed ended up hitting the gas pedal and running over the aggressive cyclists. What assholes. I was ashamed to be part of the spectacle.

Seriously, there should be 1 police officer assigned to critical mass for every 50 cyclists. They should be armed with shotguns that are loaded with bean bag rounds. When cyclists get out of line in the way I witnessed they should be shot with a bean bag round, sprayed with mace, locked up with zip ties, and get hauled off to jail.

I know the percentage of bad seeds and assholes compared to the people trying to have a fun time is small but come on. If there isn't any regulation or repercussions for cyclists who are being a public nuisance then the city should step up and stop this event.

My writing of this review was sparked by a video I saw of a motorist running over several people at critical mass who were threatening him or her. While this video should have made my blood boil, after seeing the way that some cyclists act at critical mass I can justify the drivers actions. The driver was threatened and possibly fearing for his or her life.

F*CK CRITICAL MASS. It makes me ashamed to be a cyclist.
author: g m.

description:
I can't believe this extreme negative reaction to Critical Mass. It happens every month at a set time. How can it possibly catch people by surprise? Friday after work is a prime time to grab a drink with a friend. If you don't like gay marriage, don't get one; if you don't like Critical Mass, avoid it. It's not difficult to peacefully coexist when we act respectfully toward one another, so let's all just work on that, mmkay?

So why four stars? Critical Mass gave me confidence riding a road bike on city streets when I was getting the hang of riding again, and I'm a safer cyclist for it. It gets people outside and doing something active with other people. It functions by word of mouth, by people coming together organically and inclusively and doing something even naysayers admit has prompted positive change. For a few hours each month, cyclists are (or should be) free of danger from automotive traffic, and car owners can be free of the drive to, well, drive.

I've read all the negative comments here and all I can say is you should try it sometime.

It's a mixed bag really....because it is a total disregard for other citizens who may even share the exact thoughts of you....but they just arn't on a bike. description:
Critical Mass 5-stars all the way.

But I really want to criticize some things and vent some other things and somehow use yelp as maybe an extended dialogue that I've had with lots of Mass-regular attendees like myself.  I missed maybe 4 ciritical masses in, I don't know 5 years of living here, it's important to me and I don't want to let it die.

But critical mass is not as much fun as it used to be.  I mean, this is not to say it's not fun.  But I feel like critical mass serves as a really awesome reminder to everyone.  Like, "just have fun."  You're stuck in traffic, fuck it, "just have fun."  You're riding a bike in critical mass, duh, set a good example and also "just have fun,"  and it's way better for the planet. 

So this past one was the Halloween critical mass and every year around this time I get this idea, like, that people should be in crazy funny costumes every month.  Everytime.  And try as hard as we can to make critical mass into more of a once monthly rolling street-party.  I mean, I'm so ALL FOR the political goals of critical mass, but if we're just a little more whimsical, and fun, and funny, and maybe a little less like, on edge politically, more people will get the message:  Get out of your car and have fun.  Critical mass is part of what makes San Francisco, well, San Francisco.  But I feel it should stay, well, fun, like, San Francisco.

Alas, I'm super doubtful.  I mean, no wonder critical mass isn't fun anymore.  With oil running out and gas going up and no end in sight and we're all fucked and there's this coming plague and maybe another war and we're (told to be) scared that Arabs are going to blow up the Golden Gate Bridge I guess maybe we're all a little on edge, you know?  Even the cyclists.  Actually, ESPECIALLY the cyclists.

All I'm saying is preach a little tolerance on both ends, the jackasses that come to critical mass with bikes and act too intense and the jackasses in the cars that freak out and get too upset, and maybe we'lll all be able to reflect on the absurdity of the situation of how we're yelling at each other at Broadway and Columbus and realize how fucked we truly are before it's too late.

UPDATE; It's getting funner.  There is less negativity in the air.  Hope and Change, man!  Critical Mass, 2009!

description:
Critical Mass is a truly beautiful case study in the power of numbers. Get enough people together and you can basically do anything. That's about as close as you'll probably ever get to a "point" of critical mass. 

Is it supposed to be some kind of protest? No. 
Is it a race? No.
Is it supposed to "raise awareness of bicyclists and alternative transportation"? No. 

It's basically just another version of a "flash mob". A whole lot of people together, coordinated, doing the same thing at the same time. In this case it's taking over the streets for one evening, once a month. When you're riding with the mob, it's hilariously fun. I can easily see that if you're on the other side of things, perhaps late for an appointment, trying to get up Market Street on a Friday evening, it would be infuriating. All you can do at that point is just sit, wait, and enjoy the show. The people who get visibly angry, start yelling, and basically trying to take on the whole group are really just providing more entertainment. 

Just relax. Or don't.

description:
Critical Mass is great fun! Join in! You'll have a good time!

Most of the negative reviews were written by people who have never participated in a Critical Mass ride. With the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico and all the other toxic effects of fossil fuel addiction, isn't it time to move on and do something that isn't destroying nature and our only home planet.

This is a peaceful light-hearted demonstration of how much more fun it is to ride a bike than to sit in a polluting, toxic automobile. If you're afraid of getting caught in your car and delayed 15 or 20 minutes, leave earlier or take public transport on the last Friday of the month. You can always check the critical mass website and see if the route is posted, so that you can avoid having your commute delayed. Better yet, how about leaving the car at home one day of the month and enjoy an evening of exercise and open-air relaxation on a bicycle? You won't regret it. It's a welcoming crowd and too much fun to be missed! 

Peace!

description: Critical Mass is pretty awesome.  I love the idea behind it, and I love that so many people turn up and get involved so consistently.  My issue seems to be the same as everyone else's. author: Kayti S.

description:
Activists for all variety of causes can learn something from Critical Mass: If the tactics of your activism do more to harm your cause than to help it, you probably need to find new tactics. 

To some this concept will appear excruciatingly obvious, but Critical Massers seem either oblivious or indifferent to their ineffectiveness in enacting social or political change. Maybe that's because Critical Mass is no longer about policy or environment or safety, but rather just about having a fun time in the city, everyone else be damned. The rest of society, it is implied, can just sit there and wait until the Masser's monthly exercise in arrogant self-indulgence is over. Literally just sit there.... and wait. 

Critical Massers may catch the hypocrisy in staging a monthly event that undeniably increases the output of smog and greenhouse gasses. They may even grasp the fact that their Friday rides really don't have any impact on transportation policy. But one has to wonder, do they understand the influence they have on their captive audience? Do they realize that when a parent is late picking up their kid, or a bus rider has to stand on an overloaded 38 Geary for an extra 20-plus minutes, that those individuals are not endeared to the cyclists' cause? In fact, I'd wager most people caught in a Critical Mass blockade, be they walker, bus-rider or driver, would actually feel less sympathetic, not more, to the plight of bicyclists in the city. If somehow the Massers don't see this, we should inform them immediately. We can only assume they'd see the error of their ways and adopt new, effective tactics to achieve their aims... whatever those aims may be.  It would take a 'special' kind of dedication to continue participating in a form of protest that you full well know is harming the very cause you actively support.

Just to belabor the point - when you get on your bike and partake in Critical Mass, you can't know the inconvenience you are thrusting upon the hundreds of thousands of people who are just trying to go about their everyday lives. You don't know which mothers are trying to get home to take care of their sick kid, or which commuter's are rushing to visit a dying relative in the hospital. And what really drives my antagonism is that you, Critical Masser, just don't seem to care. About anything but your fun ride.
author: Phil D.

description: This review is for Critical Mass Halloween 2008.....I've never been stuck in a nightmare traffic jam or on have I ever been majorly fucked by this monthly event, so I give last nights' CM a 4 Star review . As I waited for my lady on the corner of Market & Montgomery, the riders started to pour down Montgomery onto Market I decided to check it out. The costumes were creative and it seemed to go on for a while. The Friday Halloween CM is a once every six to eight years so people pulled out all the stops and it was a sight to behold. I'd be signing a far different tune if I was stuck on the bus, in my car or god forbid an ambulance. CM is about civil disobedience and there have been numerous incidents involving pedestrians and cars having conflict with the fringe members of the SF cycling community. I ride a bike, use public transportation and I drive a car. Try to avoid driving in the city on these Friday nights.
author: Matt H.

description:
So I've been putting this off for a few weeks now. I took part in my first Critical Mass last month (May 08). I have to say with all the criticism and harp I've heard about this gathering, it is truly an experience to be had. And to top it off, some of San Francisco's hottest, finest and coolest bikers converge then ride for 3+ hours of exhilarating biker fun.

Can't speak for impatient, ignorant car drivers that speed around in 2-3 ton junk boxes but I do know biking is in. (So glad I don't have to pay for gasoline). If you haven't tried CM, you should. It is safe at your own pace and thrilling at the lead. You can quit when you want or stay til the end. 

One last thing, this gathering IS about awareness and fun and bringing a sense of understanding and obedience on the road.  It is important to recognize there is plenty of room for both drivers and bikers. If you hate Critical Mass so much, stay inside the last Friday of the month, shut up or join us. We are all here to stay! It's that simple!
author: Tommy H.
